t: Job 1
Job’s Character and Wealth
There*p was a man in the land of Uz whose name was Job, and that man was blameless and upright, one who feared God and turned away from evil.
There were born to him seven sons and three daughters.
He possessed 7,000 sheep, 3,000 camels, 500 yoke of oxen, and 500 female donkeys, and very many servants, so that this man was the greatest of all the people of the east.
His sons used to go and hold a feast in the house of each one on his day, and they would send and invite their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

And when the days of the feast had run their course, Job would send and consecrate them, and he would rise early in the morning and offer burnt offerings according to the number of them all. For Job said, “It may be that my children have sinned, and cursed God in their hearts.” Thus Job did continually.
Satan Allowed to Test Job
Now*p there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came among them.
The Lord*s said to Satan, “From where have you come?” Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking up and down on it.”
And the Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, who fears God and turns away from evil?”
Then Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “Does Job fear God for no reason?
Have you not put a hedge around him and his house and all that he has, on every side? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
But stretch out your hand and touch all that he has, and he will curse you to your face.”
And the Lord*s said to Satan, “Behold, all that he has is in your hand. Only against him do not stretch out your hand.” So Satan went out from the presence of the Lord.*s
Satan Takes Job’s Property and Children
Now*p there was a day when his sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
and there came a messenger to Job and said, “The oxen were plowing and the donkeys feeding beside them,
and the Sabeans fell upon them and took them and struck down the servants with the edge of the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
While he was yet speaking, there came another and said, “The fire of God fell from heaven and burned up the sheep and the servants and consumed them, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”

While he was yet speaking, there came another and said, “The Chaldeans formed three groups and made a raid on the camels and took them and struck down the servants with the edge of the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
While he was yet speaking, there came another and said, “Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their oldest brother’s house,
and behold, a great wind came across the wilderness and struck the four corners of the house, and it fell upon the young people, and they are dead, and I alone have escaped to tell you.”
Then*p Job arose and tore his robe and shaved his head and fell on the ground and worshiped.
And he said, “Naked I came from my mother’s womb, and naked shall I return. The Lord*s gave, and the Lord*s has taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord.”*s
In*p all this Job did not sin or charge God with wrong.
Job 2
Satan Attacks Job’s Health
Again*p there was a day when the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord,*s and Satan also came among them to present himself before the Lord.*s
And the Lord*s said to Satan, “From where have you come?” Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “From going to and fro on the earth, and from walking up and down on it.”

And the Lord*s said to Satan, “Have you considered my servant Job, that there is none like him on the earth, a blameless and upright man, who fears God and turns away from evil? He still holds fast his integrity, although you incited me against him to destroy him without reason.”
Then Satan answered the Lord*s and said, “Skin for skin! All that a man has he will give for his life.
But stretch out your hand and touch his bone and his flesh, and he will curse you to your face.”
And the Lord*s said to Satan, “Behold, he is in your hand; only spare his life.”
So*p Satan went out from the presence of the Lord*s and struck Job with loathsome sores from the sole of his foot to the crown of his head.
And he took a piece of broken pottery with which to scrape himself while he sat in the ashes.
Then*p his wife said to him, “Do you still hold fast your integrity? Curse God and die.”
But he said to her, “You speak as one of the foolish women would speak. Shall we receive good from God, and shall we not receive evil?” In all this Job did not sin with his lips.
Job’s Three Friends

Now*p when Job’s three friends heard of all this evil that had come upon him, they came each from his own place, Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite. They made an appointment together to come to show him sympathy and comfort him.
And when they saw him from a distance, they did not recognize him. And they raised their voices and wept, and they tore their robes and sprinkled dust on their heads toward heaven.
And they sat with him on the ground seven days and seven nights, and no one spoke a word to him, for they saw that his suffering was very great.
Job 3
Job Laments His Birth
After*p this Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.
And Job said:
“Let*pn the day perish on which I was born, and*ld the night that said, ‘A*ld man is conceived.’
Let*ln that day be darkness! May*ld God above not seek it, nor*ld light shine upon it.
Let*ln gloom and deep darkness claim it. Let*ld clouds dwell upon it; let*ld the blackness of the day terrify it.
That*ln night— let thick darkness seize it! Let*ld it not rejoice among the days of the year; let*ld it not come into the number of the months.
Behold,*ln let that night be barren; let*ld no joyful cry enter it.
Let*ln those curse it who curse the day, who*ld are ready to rouse up Leviathan.
Let*ln the stars of its dawn be dark; let*ld it hope for light, but have none, nor*ld see the eyelids of the morning,
because*ln it did not shut the doors of my mother’s womb, nor*ld hide trouble from my eyes.
“Why*pn did I not die at birth, come*ld out from the womb and expire?
Why*ln did the knees receive me? Or*ld why the breasts, that I should nurse?
For*ln then I would have lain down and been quiet; I*ld would have slept; then I would have been at rest,
with*ln kings and counselors of the earth who*ld rebuilt ruins for themselves,
or*ln with princes who had gold, who*ld filled their houses with silver.
Or*ln why was I not as a hidden stillborn child, as*ld infants who never see the light?
There*ln the wicked cease from troubling, and*ld there the weary are at rest.
There*ln the prisoners are at ease together; they*ld hear not the voice of the taskmaster.
The*ln small and the great are there, and*ld the slave is free from his master.
“Why*pn is light given to him who is in misery, and*ld life to the bitter in soul,
who*ln long for death, but it comes not, and*ld dig for it more than for hidden treasures,
who*ln rejoice exceedingly and*ld are glad when they find the grave?
Why*ln is light given to a man whose way is hidden, whom*ld God has hedged in?
For*ln my sighing comes instead of my bread, and*ld my groanings are poured out like water.
For*ln the thing that I fear comes upon me, and*ld what I dread befalls me.
I*ln am not at ease, nor am I quiet; I*ld have no rest, but trouble comes.”
Job 4
Eliphaz Speaks: The Innocent Prosper
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
“If*pn one ventures a word with you, will you be impatient? Yet*ld who can keep from speaking?
Behold,*ln you have instructed many, and*ld you have strengthened the weak hands.
Your*ln words have upheld him who was stumbling, and*ld you have made firm the feeble knees.
But*ln now it has come to you, and you are impatient; it*ld touches you, and you are dismayed.
Is*ln not your fear of God your confidence, and*ld the integrity of your ways your hope?
“Remember:*pn who that was innocent ever perished? Or*ld where were the upright cut off?
As*ln I have seen, those who plow iniquity and*ld sow trouble reap the same.
By*ln the breath of God they perish, and*ld by the blast of his anger they are consumed.
The*ln roar of the lion, the voice of the fierce lion, the*ld teeth of the young lions are broken.
The*ln strong lion perishes for lack of prey, and*ld the cubs of the lioness are scattered.
“Now*pn a word was brought to me stealthily; my*ld ear received the whisper of it.
Amid*ln thoughts from visions of the night, when*ld deep sleep falls on men,
dread*ln came upon me, and trembling, which*ld made all my bones shake.
A*ln spirit glided past my face; the*ld hair of my flesh stood up.
It*ln stood still, but*ld I could not discern its appearance. A*ln form was before my eyes; there*ld was silence, then I heard a voice:
‘Can*ln mortal man be in the right before God? Can*ld a man be pure before his Maker?
Even*ln in his servants he puts no trust, and*ld his angels he charges with error;
how*ln much more those who dwell in houses of clay, whose*ld foundation is in the dust, who*ld are crushed like the moth.
Between*ln morning and evening they are beaten to pieces; they*ld perish forever without anyone regarding it.
Is*ln not their tent-cord plucked up within them, do*ld they not die, and that without wisdom?’
Job 5
“Call*pn now; is there anyone who will answer you? To*ld which of the holy ones will you turn?
Surely*ln vexation kills the fool, and*ld jealousy slays the simple.
I*ln have seen the fool taking root, but*ld suddenly I cursed his dwelling.
His*ln children are far from safety; they*ld are crushed in the gate, and*ld there is no one to deliver them.
The*ln hungry eat his harvest, and*ld he takes it even out of thorns, and*ld the thirsty pant after his wealth.
For*ln affliction does not come from the dust, nor*ld does trouble sprout from the ground,
but*ln man is born to trouble as*ld the sparks fly upward.
“As*pn for me, I would seek God, and*ld to God would I commit my cause,
who*ln does great things and unsearchable, marvelous*ld things without number:
he*ln gives rain on the earth and*ld sends waters on the fields;
he*ln sets on high those who are lowly, and*ld those who mourn are lifted to safety.
He*ln frustrates the devices of the crafty, so*ld that their hands achieve no success.
He*ln catches the wise in their own craftiness, and*ld the schemes of the wily are brought to a quick end.
They*ln meet with darkness in the daytime and*ld grope at noonday as in the night.
But*ln he saves the needy from the sword of their mouth and*ld from the hand of the mighty.
So*ln the poor have hope, and*ld injustice shuts her mouth.
“Behold,*pn blessed is the one whom God reproves; therefore*ld despise not the discipline of the Almighty.
For*ln he wounds, but he binds up; he*ld shatters, but his hands heal.
He*ln will deliver you from six troubles; in*ld seven no evil shall touch you.
In*ln famine he will redeem you from death, and*ld in war from the power of the sword.
You*ln shall be hidden from the lash of the tongue, and*ld shall not fear destruction when it comes.
At*ln destruction and famine you shall laugh, and*ld shall not fear the beasts of the earth.
For*ln you shall be in league with the stones of the field, and*ld the beasts of the field shall be at peace with you.
You*ln shall know that your tent is at peace, and*ld you shall inspect your fold and miss nothing.
You*ln shall know also that your offspring shall be many, and*ld your descendants as the grass of the earth.
You*ln shall come to your grave in ripe old age, like*ld a sheaf gathered up in its season.
Behold,*ln this we have searched out; it is true. Hear,*ld and know it for your good.”
Job 6
Job Replies: My Complaint Is Just
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Oh*pn that my vexation were weighed, and*ld all my calamity laid in the balances!
For*ln then it would be heavier than the sand of the sea; therefore*ld my words have been rash.
For*ln the arrows of the Almighty are in me; my*ld spirit drinks their poison; the*ld terrors of God are arrayed against me.
Does*ln the wild donkey bray when he has grass, or*ld the ox low over his fodder?
Can*ln that which is tasteless be eaten without salt, or*ld is there any taste in the juice of the mallow?
My*ln appetite refuses to touch them; they*ld are as food that is loathsome to me.
“Oh*pn that I might have my request, and*ld that God would fulfill my hope,
that*ln it would please God to crush me, that*ld he would let loose his hand and cut me off!
This*ln would be my comfort; I*ld would even exult in pain unsparing, for*ld I have not denied the words of the Holy One.
What*ln is my strength, that I should wait? And*ld what is my end, that I should be patient?
Is*ln my strength the strength of stones, or is my flesh bronze?
Have*ln I any help in me, when*ld resource is driven from me?
“He*pn who withholds kindness from a friend forsakes*ld the fear of the Almighty.
My*ln brothers are treacherous as a torrent-bed, as*ld torrential streams that pass away,
which*ln are dark with ice, and*ld where the snow hides itself.
When*ln they melt, they disappear; when*ld it is hot, they vanish from their place.
The*ln caravans turn aside from their course; they*ld go up into the waste and perish.
The*ln caravans of Tema look, the*ld travelers of Sheba hope.
They*ln are ashamed because they were confident; they*ld come there and are disappointed.
For*ln you have now become nothing; you*ld see my calamity and are afraid.
Have*ln I said, ‘Make me a gift’? Or,*ld ‘From your wealth offer a bribe for me’?
Or,*ln ‘Deliver me from the adversary’s hand’? Or,*ld ‘Redeem me from the hand of the ruthless’?
“Teach*pn me, and I will be silent; make*ld me understand how I have gone astray.
How*ln forceful are upright words! But*ld what does reproof from you reprove?
Do*ln you think that you can reprove words, when*ld the speech of a despairing man is wind?
You*ln would even cast lots over the fatherless, and*ld bargain over your friend.
“But*pn now, be pleased to look at me, for*ld I will not lie to your face.
Please*ln turn; let no injustice be done. Turn*ld now; my vindication is at stake.
Is*ln there any injustice on my tongue? Cannot*ld my palate discern the cause of calamity?
Job 7
Job Continues: My Life Has No Hope
“Has*pn not man a hard service on earth, and*ld are not his days like the days of a hired hand?
Like*ln a slave who longs for the shadow, and*ld like a hired hand who looks for his wages,
so*ln I am allotted months of emptiness, and*ld nights of misery are apportioned to me.
When*ln I lie down I say, ‘When shall I arise?’ But*ld the night is long, and*ld I am full of tossing till the dawn.
My*ln flesh is clothed with worms and dirt; my*ld skin hardens, then breaks out afresh.
My*ln days are swifter than a weaver’s shuttle and*ld come to their end without hope.
“Remember*pn that my life is a breath; my*ld eye will never again see good.
The*ln eye of him who sees me will behold me no more; while*ld your eyes are on me, I shall be gone.
As*ln the cloud fades and vanishes, so*ld he who goes down to Sheol does not come up;
he*ln returns no more to his house, nor*ld does his place know him anymore.
“Therefore*pn I will not restrain my mouth; I*ld will speak in the anguish of my spirit; I*ld will complain in the bitterness of my soul.
Am*ln I the sea, or a sea monster, that*ld you set a guard over me?
When*ln I say, ‘My bed will comfort me, my*ld couch will ease my complaint,’
then*ln you scare me with dreams and*ld terrify me with visions,
so*ln that I would choose strangling and*ld death rather than my bones.
I*ln loathe my life; I would not live forever. Leave*ld me alone, for my days are a breath.
What*ln is man, that you make so much of him, and*ld that you set your heart on him,
visit*ln him every morning and*ld test him every moment?
How*ln long will you not look away from me, nor*ld leave me alone till I swallow my spit?
If*ln I sin, what do I do to you, you watcher of mankind? Why*ld have you made me your mark? Why*ld have I become a burden to you?
Why*ln do you not pardon my transgression and*ld take away my iniquity? For*ln now I shall lie in the earth; you*ld will seek me, but I shall not be.”
Job 8
Bildad Speaks: Job Should Repent
Then*p Bildad the Shuhite answered and said:
“How*pn long will you say these things, and*ld the words of your mouth be a great wind?
Does*ln God pervert justice? Or*ld does the Almighty pervert the right?
If*ln your children have sinned against him, he*ld has delivered them into the hand of their transgression.
If*ln you will seek God and*ld plead with the Almighty for mercy,
if*ln you are pure and upright, surely*ld then he will rouse himself for you and*ld restore your rightful habitation.
And*ln though your beginning was small, your*ld latter days will be very great.
“For*pn inquire, please, of bygone ages, and*ld consider what the fathers have searched out.
For*ln we are but of yesterday and know nothing, for*ld our days on earth are a shadow.
Will*ln they not teach you and tell you and*ld utter words out of their understanding?
“Can*pn papyrus grow where there is no marsh? Can*ld reeds flourish where there is no water?
While*ln yet in flower and not cut down, they*ld wither before any other plant.
Such*ln are the paths of all who forget God; the*ld hope of the godless shall perish.
His*ln confidence is severed, and*ld his trust is a spider’s web.
He*ln leans against his house, but it does not stand; he*ld lays hold of it, but it does not endure.
He*ln is a lush plant before the sun, and*ld his shoots spread over his garden.
His*ln roots entwine the stone heap; he*ld looks upon a house of stones.
If*ln he is destroyed from his place, then*ld it will deny him, saying, ‘I have never seen you.’
Behold,*ln this is the joy of his way, and*ld out of the soil others will spring.
“Behold,*pn God will not reject a blameless man, nor*ld take the hand of evildoers.
He*ln will yet fill your mouth with laughter, and*ld your lips with shouting.
Those*ln who hate you will be clothed with shame, and*ld the tent of the wicked will be no more.”
Job 9
Job Replies: There Is No Arbiter
Then*p Job answered and said:
“Truly*pn I know that it is so: But*ld how can a man be in the right before God?
If*ln one wished to contend with him, one*ld could not answer him once in a thousand times.
He*ln is wise in heart and mighty in strength— who has hardened himself against him, and succeeded?—
he*ln who removes mountains, and they know it not, when*ld he overturns them in his anger,
who*ln shakes the earth out of its place, and*ld its pillars tremble;
who*ln commands the sun, and it does not rise; who*ld seals up the stars;
who*ln alone stretched out the heavens and*ld trampled the waves of the sea;
who*ln made the Bear and Orion, the*ld Pleiades and the chambers of the south;
who*ln does great things beyond searching out, and*ld marvelous things beyond number.
Behold,*ln he passes by me, and I see him not; he*ld moves on, but I do not perceive him.
Behold,*ln he snatches away; who can turn him back? Who*ld will say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
“God*pn will not turn back his anger; beneath*ld him bowed the helpers of Rahab.
How*ln then can I answer him, choosing*ld my words with him?
Though*ln I am in the right, I cannot answer him; I*ld must appeal for mercy to my accuser.
If*ln I summoned him and he answered me, I*ld would not believe that he was listening to my voice.
For*ln he crushes me with a tempest and*ld multiplies my wounds without cause;
he*ln will not let me get my breath, but*ld fills me with bitterness.
If*ln it is a contest of strength, behold, he is mighty! If*ld it is a matter of justice, who can summon him?
Though*ln I am in the right, my own mouth would condemn me; though*ld I am blameless, he would prove me perverse.
I*ln am blameless; I regard not myself; I*ld loathe my life.
It*ln is all one; therefore I say, ‘He*ld destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’
When*ln disaster brings sudden death, he*ld mocks at the calamity of the innocent.
The*ln earth is given into the hand of the wicked; he*ld covers the faces of its judges— if*ld it is not he, who then is it?
“My*pn days are swifter than a runner; they*ld flee away; they see no good.
They*ln go by like skiffs of reed, like*ld an eagle swooping on the prey.
If*ln I say, ‘I will forget my complaint, I*ld will put off my sad face, and be of good cheer,’
I*ln become afraid of all my suffering, for*ld I know you will not hold me innocent.
I*ln shall be condemned; why*ld then do I labor in vain?
If*ln I wash myself with snow and*ld cleanse my hands with lye,
yet*ln you will plunge me into a pit, and*ld my own clothes will abhor me.
For*ln he is not a man, as I am, that I might answer him, that*ld we should come to trial together.
There*ln is no arbiter between us, who*ld might lay his hand on us both.
Let*ln him take his rod away from me, and*ld let not dread of him terrify me.
Then*ln I would speak without fear of him, for*ld I am not so in myself.
Job 10
Job Continues: A Plea to God
“I*pn loathe my life; I*ln will give free utterance to my complaint; I*ld will speak in the bitterness of my soul.
I*ln will say to God, Do not condemn me; let*ld me know why you contend against me.
Does*ln it seem good to you to oppress, to*ld despise the work of your hands and*ld favor the designs of the wicked?
Have*ln you eyes of flesh? Do*ld you see as man sees?
Are*ln your days as the days of man, or*ld your years as a man’s years,
that*ln you seek out my iniquity and*ld search for my sin,
although*ln you know that I am not guilty, and*ld there is none to deliver out of your hand?
Your*ln hands fashioned and made me, and*ld now you have destroyed me altogether.
Remember*ln that you have made me like clay; and*ld will you return me to the dust?
Did*ln you not pour me out like milk and*ld curdle me like cheese?
You*ln clothed me with skin and flesh, and*ld knit me together with bones and sinews.
You*ln have granted me life and steadfast love, and*ld your care has preserved my spirit.
Yet*ln these things you hid in your heart; I*ld know that this was your purpose.
If*ln I sin, you watch me and*ld do not acquit me of my iniquity.
If*ln I am guilty, woe to me! If*ld I am in the right, I cannot lift up my head, for*ln I am filled with disgrace and*ld look on my affliction.
And*ln were my head lifted up, you would hunt me like a lion and*ld again work wonders against me.
You*ln renew your witnesses against me and*ld increase your vexation toward me; you*ld bring fresh troops against me.
“Why*pn did you bring me out from the womb? Would*ld that I had died before any eye had seen me
and*ln were as though I had not been, carried*ld from the womb to the grave.
Are*ln not my days few? Then*ld cease, and leave me alone, that I may find a little cheer
before*ln I go— and I shall not return— to*ld the land of darkness and deep shadow,
the*ln land of gloom like thick darkness, like*ld deep shadow without any order, where*ld light is as thick darkness.”
Job 11
Zophar Speaks: You Deserve Worse
Then*p Zophar the Naamathite answered and said:
“Should*pn a multitude of words go unanswered, and*ld a man full of talk be judged right?
Should*ln your babble silence men, and*ld when you mock, shall no one shame you?
For*ln you say, ‘My doctrine is pure, and*ld I am clean in God’s eyes.’
But*ln oh, that God would speak and*ld open his lips to you,
and*ln that he would tell you the secrets of wisdom! For*ld he is manifold in understanding. Know*ln then that God exacts of you less than your guilt deserves.
“Can*pn you find out the deep things of God? Can*ld you find out the limit of the Almighty?
It*ln is higher than heaven— what can you do? Deeper*ld than Sheol— what can you know?
Its*ln measure is longer than the earth and*ld broader than the sea.
If*ln he passes through and imprisons and*ld summons the court, who can turn him back?
For*ln he knows worthless men; when*ld he sees iniquity, will he not consider it?
But*ln a stupid man will get understanding when*ld a wild donkey’s colt is born a man!
“If*pn you prepare your heart, you*ld will stretch out your hands toward him.
If*ln iniquity is in your hand, put it far away, and*ld let not injustice dwell in your tents.
Surely*ln then you will lift up your face without blemish; you*ld will be secure and will not fear.
You*ln will forget your misery; you*ld will remember it as waters that have passed away.
And*ln your life will be brighter than the noonday; its*ld darkness will be like the morning.
And*ln you will feel secure, because there is hope; you*ld will look around and take your rest in security.
You*ln will lie down, and none will make you afraid; many*ld will court your favor.
But*ln the eyes of the wicked will fail; all*ld way of escape will be lost to them, and*ld their hope is to breathe their last.”
Job 12
Job Replies: The Lord Has Done This
Then*p Job answered and said:
“No*pn doubt you are the people, and*ld wisdom will die with you.
But*ln I have understanding as well as you; I*ld am not inferior to you. Who*ld does not know such things as these?
I*ln am a laughingstock to my friends; I,*ld who called to God and he answered me, a*ld just and blameless man, am a laughingstock.
In*ln the thought of one who is at ease there is contempt for misfortune; it*ld is ready for those whose feet slip.
The*ln tents of robbers are at peace, and*ld those who provoke God are secure, who*ld bring their god in their hand.
“But*pn ask the beasts, and they will teach you; the*ld birds of the heavens, and they will tell you;
or*ln the bushes of the earth, and they will teach you; and*ld the fish of the sea will declare to you.
Who*ln among all these does not know that*ld the hand of the Lord*s has done this?
In*ln his hand is the life of every living thing and*ld the breath of all mankind.
Does*ln not the ear test words as*ld the palate tastes food?
Wisdom*ln is with the aged, and*ld understanding in length of days.
“With*pn God are wisdom and might; he*ld has counsel and understanding.
If*ln he tears down, none can rebuild; if*ld he shuts a man in, none can open.
If*ln he withholds the waters, they dry up; if*ld he sends them out, they overwhelm the land.
With*ln him are strength and sound wisdom; the*ld deceived and the deceiver are his.
He*ln leads counselors away stripped, and*ld judges he makes fools.
He*ln looses the bonds of kings and*ld binds a waistcloth on their hips.
He*ln leads priests away stripped and*ld overthrows the mighty.
He*ln deprives of speech those who are trusted and*ld takes away the discernment of the elders.
He*ln pours contempt on princes and*ld loosens the belt of the strong.
He*ln uncovers the deeps out of darkness and*ld brings deep darkness to light.
He*ln makes nations great, and he destroys them; he*ld enlarges nations, and leads them away.
He*ln takes away understanding from the chiefs of the people of the earth and*ld makes them wander in a trackless waste.
They*ln grope in the dark without light, and*ld he makes them stagger like a drunken man.
Job 13
Job Continues: Still I Will Hope in God
“Behold,*pn my eye has seen all this, my*ld ear has heard and understood it.
What*ln you know, I also know; I*ld am not inferior to you.
But*ln I would speak to the Almighty, and*ld I desire to argue my case with God.
As*ln for you, you whitewash with lies; worthless*ld physicians are you all.
Oh*ln that you would keep silent, and*ld it would be your wisdom!
Hear*ln now my argument and*ld listen to the pleadings of my lips.
Will*ln you speak falsely for God and*ld speak deceitfully for him?
Will*ln you show partiality toward him? Will*ld you plead the case for God?
Will*ln it be well with you when he searches you out? Or*ld can you deceive him, as one deceives a man?
He*ln will surely rebuke you if*ld in secret you show partiality.
Will*ln not his majesty terrify you, and*ld the dread of him fall upon you?
